title: Food Allergy Diagnosis and How It Affects Baking and Cooking

content: When my son was diagnosed with a food allergy to peanut and shellfish, we felt as if things were being taken away left and right. This held true for many foods including if it had the actual ingredient, was listed as "may contain," or was subject to cross-contact in the kitchen of a restaurant or home. Fast-forward several years later when he gained additional allergies, including some outside the top 9 such as being anaphylactic to garlic, and our world seemed to shrink even more.
Opening Up a World of Possibilities With Baking and Cooking Substitutions

As we learned the magic of substitutions, our world quickly increased again. We learned that we could re-create nearly any dish or recipe with the help of substitutions. It is important to note that not all allergies are created equal, nor is each individual, as a person or with regard to their food allergies. When considering substitutions, there may be an individual, for example, that is allergic to peanuts, cow’s milk, and all tree nuts except for coconut. For that person, coconut milk may be an option they could discuss with their allergist, even though it is lumped in with other tree nuts, because it may serve to open doors for them in substituting for cow’s milk. What works for one person may not work for another. The hope is that by learning about potential options, doors will reopen that may have been temporarily closed due to a food allergy diagnosis.

sections.heading: Peanut, Tree Nut, and Seed Allergy Substitution Options
content: If you manage a peanut or seed allergy, the commonly used peanut butter or it’s heavily used substitute, sunflower seed butter, may not be an option. There are other butters out there including soy butter, almond butter, walnut butter, cookie butter, and granola butter, to name a few. You will want to check with each manufacturer to ensure it will be something safe for you. Typically, with butters you can do an even exchange. If a peanut butter cookie recipe called for 1 cup of peanut butter, you should be able to substitute it equally for 1 cup of sunflower seed butter, for example.

sections.heading: Wheat Allergy Substitution Options
content: If you are wheat free and find an allergy friendly measure-for-measure flour substitute, many on the market are just what their name implies, measure for measure or equal ratio substituting for all-purpose flour.

Wheat and traditional baking can be very cumbersome, especially for the beginner baker. Don’t let this stop you from baking all your favorite foods. However, while you acquire a new skill set for wheat-free baking, do take heart in knowing that there are also many ready-made wheat-free products at your local grocery store including bread loaves, cinnamon rolls, bagels, and more!

sections.heading: Milk Allergy Substitution Options
content: When it comes to butter made from traditional cow’s milk, you can often substitute vegan butter, oil, or shortening with an equal ratio of 1:1. Some oils that we have loved to use in our baking include grapeseed, olive oil, canola oil, avocado, and coconut oil.

When using milk in a recipe, such as pancakes, waffles, or even muffins, we have also been able to substitute with grocery store alternatives such as flax, rice, soy, oat, hemp, almond, cashew, pea, and coconut milk. I have even used a pancake mix and substituted water in place of the called-for milk. Again, I used an equal 1:1 ratio.

Whipped cream can be a tough one if you have a cow’s milk allergy. However, if you are not allergic to coconut, this can make an amazing whipped cream. I store mine in the can it comes in, in the refrigerator, overnight. Drain excess liquid prior to blending, and using an electric hand mixer, I whip until soft peaks are formed.

For other cow’s milk products such as cream cheese, shredded cheese, sliced cheese, or even yogurt, there are fortunately many products available on the market now. It is important to not just trust brand messaging such as “vegan” and assume it will be safe. Read every label, every time, each individual ingredient. Often, marketing messages such as “vegan” can be misleading, and you may find your allergen lurking in the ingredients.

sections.heading: Egg Allergy Substitution Options
content: When baking or cooking with egg allergy, there are several options for substitutions that can work quite well. This is one that sometimes takes trial and error, however, to figure out which is the best option for each recipe. What works well for one type of recipe may not work well for another, especially if a recipe calls for more than about three eggs. In that situation there is a liquid egg replacement product that might fit the bill for those special times when large quantities of egg are in a single recipe.
In baking you can often substitute for each egg, ONE of the following:
bullets: 1 tablespoon chia seeds mixed with 1/4 cup hot water and allowed to set for 5-10 minutes prior to adding to recipe as substitution.
1 tablespoon ground flaxseed combined with 3 tablespoons hot water and allowed to set for 5-10 minutes prior to adding to recipe as substitution.

sections.heading: Recipe for Aquafaba:
content: Liquid from one (15-ounce) can of garbanzo beans
1/4 teaspoon cream of tartar

Drain liquid from beans. Set beans aside for other use, as you will not use the actual beans in this recipe. Combine the liquid from beans and cream of tartar with an electric handheld mixer until soft peaks are formed. This may take several minutes. Makes approximately 2 cups aquafaba. This is great in replacement of egg whites, about 2 tablespoons of aquafaba per egg white. Three tablespoons for each whole egg called for in a recipe.
Soy Allergy Substitution Options

One of my favorite substitutions to use in place of soy sauce in recipes is soy-free coconut aminos! This can be substituted in equal portions as called for in the recipe. For example, 1 cup soy sauce can be replaced with 1 cup soy-free coconut aminos. Optionally, add 1/2 teaspoon salt for each 1 cup coconut aminos. If you are managing both a soy and coconut allergy, this substitute would not work for you.

sections.heading: Baking and Cooking Can Be Fun and Rewarding
content: While the substitutes listed are not all-encompassing or a catchall for every allergen, nor for every individual, this is a good foundation for many of the top 9 allergens that are frequently used in both baking and cooking recipes.

Keep in mind that not all substitutes can be relied on for every recipe. There will be some success as well as some failures. Learn from those kitchen failures and try again with another substitute. When you find the winning substitute for your great grandmother’s tried-and-true family muffin recipe, note that for next time!
Read Every Label, Every Time

As mentioned regarding marketing and other labels on products that may say “vegan,” for example, when shopping for and using substitutions, remember that a lot of marketing messaging and what we read on products is not part of the Food Allergen Labeling and Consumer Protection Act of 2004, also known as FALCPA.

It is essential to take the time to read the ingredient label of every product, every time. A rule of thumb is to read it when purchasing it in the store, read it again before putting it away at home, and read it a third time before using it in the kitchen in one of your favorite recipes.
